context_meta.title: NBA mock drafts: Experts weigh in on Phoenix Suns' options at No. 1 in 2018 NBA draft
context_meta.summary: On Tuesday, the Suns made history, landing the No. 1 pick in the NBA draft for the first time. After finishing 21-61 last season, the Suns front office is looking to turn the team around – quickly. With the draft order set, NBA experts weigh in on whom they see the Suns taking first. No. 1 pick: While Suns General Manager Ryan McDonough did not reveal which way the Suns are leaning, the general feeling from those who cover the NBA is that Deandre Ayton is the top choice, just edging out Slovenian guard Luka Doncic. Both have ties to Arizona, with Ayton having played at the University of Arizona, and with Doncic playing under newly hired Suns coach Igor Kokoskov. While that tie is enough to keep

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Steve Kerr had a funny response to Curry question
context_meta.summary: It's a fair question to ask: Is Steph Curry's injury still lingering, particularly when he's hit just two of his 13 threes in the Western Conference Finals and he shot 7-of-19 on Wednesday? How much is that a factor? Warriors coach Steve Kerr, however, couldn't help but sarcastically joke in response: He also thought the Dubs "got what we deserved": Kerr continues to be the best, even in the face of a playoff loss.

context_meta.title: The Heat granted this front office member permission to interview for another NBA job
context_meta.summary: Shane Battier spent three years with the Miami Heat as a player, won two NBA Championships while in South Florida and spent the last 15 months as a member of the Heat's front office. His time with the Heat organization, however, could be coming to an end. The Heat granted Battier permission to interview with the Detroit Pistons for an unspecified front office job. Battier is a native of Birmingham, Michigan, which is just outside of Detroit. Battier, 39, joined the Heat front office in February 2017 as its director of basketball development and analytics and is responsible for "the development of analytics in evaluating all talent, including college, free agents and current Miami players," according

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Throwback: Kuzma and Ingram's Overtime Duel
context_meta.summary: When Kyle Kuzma held a recent Q&A session with his Twitter followers, one answer brought back memories of a battle between future Lakers forwards. Asked for the best player he faced in college, Kuzma replied with two letters. Back on Dec. 19, 2015, Kuzma's Utah Utes faced off against Brandon Ingram and the seventh-ranked Duke Blue Devils in a wild contest at Madison Square Garden. Both players cooked, with Kuzma scoring a team-high 21 points, while Ingram packaged together 15 points, three steals and three blocks. They also flashed the skill sets that would soon make them valuable pieces of the Lakers' young core. The future teammates guarded each other all night long, and Ingram seized the immediate

context_meta.title: NBA award finalists revealed: James Harden, LeBron James, Anthony Davis headline MVP list
context_meta.summary: SportsPulse: LeBron James finished Game 2 with a 40-plus-point triple-double but it wasn't enough as the Celtics remained undefeated in Boston in the playoffs. Either James Harden, LeBron James or Anthony Davis will be this year's NBA MVP, it was announced Wednesday night on TNT prior to Game 2 of the Western Conference finals between Golden State and Houston. Harden, widely considered the favorite to take home the hardware, led Houston to a franchise-best 65 wins, but James put together what was arguably the best season of his career and Davis kicked his game into another gear following teammate DeMarcus Cousins' season-ending injury in January. context_meta.title: Suns' top choice? ESPN Euro expert Fran Fraschilla would take Deandre Ayton at No. 1
context_meta.summary: CHICAGO – The debate is on. Should the Suns take University of Arizona center Deandre Ayton or Slovenian guard Luka Doncic with the No. 1 pick in the June 21 NBA draft? Already, opinions are forming on both sides. Sacramento point guard De'Aaron Fox told reporters after Tuesday's lottery that he believes it's a “given” Phoenix will take Ayton. But ESPN NBA analyst Amin Elhassan, during an appearance Wednesday on the “Golic and Wingo” show, said he would take Doncic because: “I look at the Suns and what they need … they're one of the worst passing teams. context_meta.title: Jerry West on leaving the Warriors: 'You have to be wanted'
context_meta.summary: Last year at this time, Jerry West was on the payroll of the Golden State Warriors. He'd come to the team in 2011 and helped build the transcendental dynasty we know today. As we speak, West is on the payroll of the Los Angeles Clippers, a franchise that for 48 years has drifted from raging incompetence to unrequited success, and back. A recent New York Times profile of the man they call The Logo confirmed that West is a healthy, ridiculously accomplished, 79-year-old who can golf his age. context_meta.summary: Could there be an all-Kentucky NBA "super team" one day? At least one former Cat, the Sacramento Kings' Willie Cauley-Stein, has thought about it. “That's crazy. I literally just asked (Devin) Booker about that three weeks ago,” Cauley-Stein said Tuesday, according to Inquirer.net, the website of the Philippines Daily Inquirer. Cauley-Stein is in the Philippines to help coach the 2018 Junior NBA Training Camp finalists along with WNBA legend Sheryl Swoopes, according to the Kings' team blog. Cauley-Stein just completed his third and most successful season for the Kings, averaging 12.8 points and seven rebounds per game.
